channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Strong Dollar Is Good for the US but Bad for the World
item.description: The Federal Reserve may have no choice but to wage a relentless inflation fight, but countries rich and poor are feeling the pain of plunging currencies.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: When it comes to global finance and trade, the United States has outsize influence.

item.title: Why a Weak British Pound Matters
item.description: Investors briefly sent the pound to a record low against the dollar, which has implications for people and businesses inside and outside Britain.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: The British pound briefly hit a record low against the dollar on Monday.

item.title: Two Cities, Two Armies: Pivot Points in the Fight in Ukraine’s East
item.description: The battle for the critical Donbas region in Ukraine is centered on two strategically important cities: Lyman, held by the Russians, and Bakhmut, held by Ukraine. The fighting over the cities is fierce as both armies race to claim new ground.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

item.title: Edward Snowden Receives Russian Citizenship
item.description: Mr. Snowden, a former intelligence contractor, left the United States after giving hundreds of highly classified N.S.A. documents to The Guardian and The Washington Post in 2013.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: Edward Snowden speaking during an online forum in Moscow last year.

item.title: Giorgia Meloni's Election Win in Italy: Here’s What To Know
item.description: Giorgia Meloni, leader of the hard-right Brothers of Italy, looked set to become prime minister after her party garnered more votes than any other.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Giorgia Meloni holding a sign reading “Thank you Italy” at a news conference on Monday. She is almost certain to become Italy’s first female prime minister.

item.title: Europe Looks at Italy’s Giorgia Meloni With Caution and Trepidation
item.description: Giorgia Meloni, poised to be the country’s first far-right leader since Mussolini, says she supports Ukraine and has moderated her harsh views on Europe, but there are doubts, given her partners.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Giorgia Meloni leaving the polling station where she voted in Rome on Sunday. Her Brothers of Italy received the highest vote total of any single party, according to preliminary results.

item.title: Meloni Faces Early Test of Italy’s Resolve on Russia and Ukraine
item.description: The hard-right leader Giorgia Meloni has been a full-throated supporter of Ukraine, but her coalition partners have sounded like apologists for Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Giorgia Meloni on Monday after early projections had her coalition winning a majority in Italy’s Parliament. She has unambiguously criticized Russia’s aggression in Ukraine.

item.title: More Trans Teens Are Choosing ‘Top Surgery’
item.description: Small studies suggest that breast removal surgery improves transgender teenagers’ well-being, but data is sparse. Some state leaders oppose such procedures for minors.
item.dc:creator: Azeen Ghorayshi
item.category: World Professional Association for Transgender Health
item.media:credit: Eva Marie Uzcategui for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Sidhbh Gallagher’s unusual embrace of social media platforms like TikTok has made her one of the most visible surgeons in her field.

item.title: Hurricane Ian Could Gain Strength Rapidly. Here’s Why.
item.description: Storms that intensify quickly and unpredictably present a big problem for public safety officials, who have less time to assess threats.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.media:description: A firefighter in Bourg, La., during Hurricane Ida last year. Wind speeds in the storm rose to 150 miles per hour, from 85 m.p.h., in less than 24 hours.

item.title: Some Floridians Urged to Begin Evacuating as Hurricane Ian Strengthens
item.description: Hillsborough County, which includes Tampa, issued an evacuation order for low-lying areas. Cuba was also preparing for life-threatening storm surge and evacuations in some western provinces.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: How New Mexico’s Largest Wildfire Set Off a Drinking Water Crisis
item.description: In a community ravaged by fire, floods and contaminated drinking water, residents wonder, ‘What’s next?’ And who will pick up the bill?
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Adria Malcolm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Part of the burn scar from the Calf Canyon/Hermits Peak fire in northern New Mexico.

item.title: Iran Strikes Kurdish Separatist Groups in Northern Iraq
item.description: The death of a young Iranian Kurdish woman in police custody has set off an intense wave of protests across Iran over the past 10 days, igniting fury particularly in the country’s Kurdish minority community.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht and Jane Arraf
item.media:description: Women protesting the killing of Mahsa Amini in Erbil, the capital of the semiautonomous Kurdistan region in northern Iraq, on Saturday.

item.title: Republicans Intensify Attacks on Crime as Democrats Push Back
item.description: With images of lawlessness, G.O.P. candidates are pressing the issue in places where worries about public safety are omnipresent. Democrats, on the defensive, are promising to fund the police.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Jonathan Weisman
item.media:description: Police officers in Gresham, Ore., a Portland suburb, in July. Worries about crime and homelessness are widespread in Portland and other cities Republicans are highlighting in political messaging.

item.title: Doug Mastriano’s Sputtering Campaign: No TV Ads, Tiny Crowds, Little Money
item.description: As he runs for governor of Pennsylvania, Doug Mastriano is being heavily outspent by his Democratic rival and trails badly in polling. National Republicans show little desire to help him.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times
item.media:description: Doug Mastriano spoke to a few dozen supporters on Saturday in front of the State Capitol in Harrisburg, Pa. Days before, his running mate, Carrie Lewis DelRosso, had urged supporters to attend “the big rally.”

item.title: Ghosts of New York’s Glamorous Past Haunt an Empty Pub
item.description: A bar from the Stork Club, once a gathering spot for Grace Kelly, Ernest Hemingway, Elizabeth Taylor and Marilyn Monroe, collects dust in a downtown tavern that went out of business.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vadukul
item.media:credit: Lila Barth for The New York Times
item.media:description: The proprietor of Jim Brady’s, a Manhattan pub that went out of business at the start of the pandemic, said that a bar once part of the fabled Stork Club was brought piece by piece to his tavern in the 1970s.

item.title: The End of the $25,000 NFL Rookie Dinner?
item.description: Young athletes are expected to treat their veteran teammates to an exorbitant meal. Is it a form of team bonding — or hazing by another name?
item.dc:creator: Priya Krishna

item.title: A Brooklyn Top-Floor Loft for $500 a Month
item.description: Jens Rasmussen and Maria Aparo couldn’t walk away from Mr. Rasmussen’s spacious loft in Greenpoint, which is covered under New York’s 1982 Loft Law.
item.dc:creator: D.W. Gibson
item.media:description: “I’m thankful for the loft law — so thankful. Without it, we wouldn’t be able to stay in the city,” said Jens Rasmussen, left, sitting in the apartment he shares with Maria Aparo and their son, Luca.

item.title: Biden’s Cautious Foreign Policy Is Imperiling the United States
item.description: We have let Russian threats determine our actions, which encourages Russia and others to test our resolve.
item.dc:creator: Kori Schake
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Biden after delivering remarks at the United Nations General Assembly on Wednesday.

item.title: The Dangers of Election-Denying Secretary of State Campaigns
item.description: Republican Dominic Rapini is unlikely to become Connecticut’s secretary of state, but election-denying candidacies like his are still damaging.
item.dc:creator: Chris Geidner

item.title: Where Are All Our Post-Covid Patients?
item.description: Post-Covid care has become a luxury.
item.dc:creator: Daniela J. Lamas

item.title: Italy’s Giorgia Meloni Is Extreme, but She’s no Tyrant
item.description: She couldn’t turn Italy into Hungary even if she wanted to.
item.dc:creator: Mattia Ferraresi
item.media:description: A rally organized by the major right-wing parties, in Rome this month.

item.title: Does It Matter That Investigators Are Closing In on Trump?
item.description: He is not the only politician in America, even if it sometimes feels that way.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
item.media:description: The former president famously said his voters wouldn’t care if he stood in the middle of Fifth Avenue and shot someone. He may have a point.

item.title: The Joy of Finding People Who Love the Same Books You Do
item.description: To be read to is a form of holiness.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Renkl

item.title: The Uber Hack Exposes More Than Failed Data Security
item.description: We need strong regulations that force organizations to maintain good security practices.
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Do Not Bring Your ‘Whole Self’ to Work
item.description: Beware the latest fad from Human Resources.
item.dc:creator: Pamela Paul

item.title: Iran’s Ferocious Dissent
item.description: Times reporters make sense of what’s happening.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A protest in Tehran last week over the death of a 22-year-old woman, Mahsa Amini, in police custody this month.

item.title: What’s Behind the Steep Decline in Child Poverty in America?
item.description: There are some surprising reasons why millions fewer U.S. children are growing up poor today compared with 30 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Nina Feldman, Stella Tan, Michael Simon Johnson, Patricia Willens, Marc Georges, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Jackson family in West Virginia benefits from a safety net that has expanded significantly over the last generation.

item.title: A Pesto for Every Pantry and Mood
item.description: Use the Ligurian sauce as a guideline and make tastier sandwiches, soups, pastas, gratins and more.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.media:credit: Jessica Emily Marx for The New York Times

item.title: Are You Finally Back in the Office? Tell Us How You’re Managing
item.description: For those who worked from home for two-and-a-half years and are only now returning to an office, an entire lifestyle needs to be undone or readjusted. We want to hear about it.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Grand Central Station in New York City.

item.title: ‘Let’s Do It Legit’: Drug Arrestees Vie for First New York Pot Licenses
item.description: People who have been punished for marijuana offenses are applying to open the state’s first retail cannabis dispensaries.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Southall
item.media:credit: Elias Williams for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hector Bonilla, among the first applicants for a recreational dispensary license, said he was arrested and charged with possession of marijuana decades earlier.

item.title: How to Watch NASA’s DART Spacecraft Slam Into an Asteroid
item.description: The DART mission has been flying to its target since launching last year. On Monday night, it will connect.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang

item.title: Jim Florio, New Jersey Governor Undone by Tax Hike, Dies at 85
item.description: A Democrat, he had successes on gun control, the environment and property-tax relief, but after raising income and sales taxes, he lost a bid for re-election.
item.dc:creator: Joseph P. Fried
item.media:credit: Laura Pedrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jim Florio and his wife, Lucinda, rear, at a New Jersey Democratic Party event in Camden in 1999. He said he had no choice but to raise taxes to balance the state budget after taking office in 1990.

item.title: To Defend Democracy, Is Brazil’s Top Court Going Too Far?
item.description: Brazil’s Supreme Court has acted as the primary check on President Jair Bolsonaro’s power. Now many are worried the court is posing its own threat.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and André Spigariol

item.title: UTI Treatment: What to Know About Supplements and Prevention
item.description: More than half of American women will have a urinary tract infection during their lives. But can supplements really stave that off?
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: Know Your Uterus
item.description: Endometriosis, fibroid tumors and structural anomalies are just a few conditions that can impact uterine health.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Hobson

item.title: Postpartum Body Changes You Should Know About
item.description: From separated abs to pelvic floor issues, what to look out for after having a baby.
item.dc:creator: Anna Nowogrodzki

item.title: This Chemical Can Impair Fertility, but It’s Hard to Avoid
item.description: Hormone-disrupting phthalates can be found in everything from plastics and household goods to personal care products. Studies have shown they may be harmful to women’s reproductive systems.
item.dc:creator: Liza Gross

item.title: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome: What It Is, How to Manage It
item.description: Often misunderstood and misdiagnosed, PCOS can play havoc with your fertility. Here’s how to recognize the symptoms and take action to protect your reproductive health.
item.dc:creator: Hilda Hutcherson

item.title: In ‘Joyce’s Women,’ 2 Great Irish Writers Square Up
item.description: Edna O’Brien’s latest stage work, at the Abbey Theater in Dublin, imagines the inner lives of important female figures around James Joyce.
item.dc:creator: Roisin Kiberd
item.media:credit: Ellius Grace for The New York Times
item.media:description: Genevieve Hulme Beaman, who plays Lucia Joyce in “Joyce’s Women,” in rehearsal at the Abbey Theater in September.

item.title: How to Solve Beginner Crosswords
item.description: Get started solving the Mini, Monday and Tuesday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
